Satisfy a large number of design constraints and concerns Select the correct answer from the options below:

questions.question_text_1: In the Double Diamond Design Process introduced by the British Design Council, the design journey involves two main divergence and convergence phases: one for identifying the right problem and another for developing the right solution. During this process, what do the X and Y axes most likely represent in the Double Diamond diagram?
questions.question_text_2: In the Double Diamond Design Process introduced by the British Design Council, the design journey involves two main divergence and convergence phases: one for identifying the right problem and another for developing the right solution. During this process, what do the X and Y axes most likely represent in the Double Diamond diagram?

options.option_text: Ananyaa, frustrated with corporate life, quits her job to start her own designconsulting firm.
Rohan, a marketing executive, creates a new customer loyalty app for hiscompany and leads its rollout.
Mohak’s firm hires an external agency to design an innovative supply chainsystem.
Aastha, co-founder of a small startup, pitches his product idea to venturecapitalists for funding.

questions.question_text_1: When testing a prototype, which of the following practices align with effective user testing principles? 1. Select participants who closely match the target population. 2. Test prototypes in conditions that mimic real-world use as closely as possible. 3. Use paired participants occasionally to encourage open discussion of thoughts and frustrations. How many of the above statements are correct?
question_texts: When testing a prototype, which of the following practices align with effective user testing principles? 1. Select participants who closely match the target population. 2. Test prototypes in conditions that mimic real-world use as closely as possible. 3. Use paired participants occasionally to encourage open discussion of thoughts and frustrations. How many of the above statements are correct?

questions.question_text_1: During a design thinking hackathon promotion, the organizing team spent ₹15,000 on general outreach and an additional ₹8,400 to boost a specific social media post. That boosted post alone resulted in 300 registration app installs. What was the Cost Per Install (CPI)?
question_texts: During a design thinking hackathon promotion, the organizing team spent ₹15,000 on general outreach and an additional ₹8,400 to boost a specific social media post. That boosted post alone resulted in 300 registration app installs. What was the Cost Per Install (CPI)?

questions.question_text_1: In practical web design, applying the peak-end rule means focusing on:
question_texts: In practical web design, applying the peak-end rule means focusing on:

options.option_text: Loading speed and bounce rate metrics only
Creating a highly engaging moment during the experience and ending on asatisfying note
Increasing the total time users spend on the site regardless of content qualityand ending on a satisfying note
Maximizing the number of clickable elements on each page

questions.question_text_1: An engineer develops a novel algorithm entirely on their own time, using personal equipment, but based on an idea discussed in a company meeting where the engineer is under employee contract. Who is the inventor, and who typically owns the IP?
question_texts: An engineer develops a novel algorithm entirely on their own time, using personal equipment, but based on an idea discussed in a company meeting where the engineer is under employee contract. Who is the inventor, and who typically owns the IP?

options.option_text: The company is the inventor and company is typically the owner
The engineer is the inventor; the company may own the IP
The engineer is both the inventor and owner by default
The company is the inventor; the engineer owns the IP

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements about Intellectual Property (IP) are correct? 1. Copyright protects original expressions, not ideas. 2. Patents protect inventions even if not novel and obvious. 3. Trade secrets must be publicly disclosed to be protected. 4. Trademarks protect brand identifiers like logos and names. Select the correct answer:
question_texts: Which of the following statements about Intellectual Property (IP) are correct? 1. Copyright protects original expressions, not ideas. 2. Patents protect inventions even if not novel and obvious. 3. Trade secrets must be publicly disclosed to be protected. 4. Trademarks protect brand identifiers like logos and names. Select the correct answer:

questions.question_text_1: While evaluating a new health-tracking mobile app, the UX research team observed several aspects as given below: 1. The emotional reactions users had while navigating the app. 2. The beliefs users held about the app’s accuracy and trustworthiness. 3. The perceptions users formed about the app’s design and ease of use. 4. The physical and psychological responses triggered during usage (e.g., eye strain, sense of accomplishment). 5. The behaviours users displayed while interacting with the app (e.g., checking it daily, avoiding certain features). Which of the above aspects are typically considered part of User Experience (UX)?
question_texts: While evaluating a new health-tracking mobile app, the UX research team observed several aspects as given below: 1. The emotional reactions users had while navigating the app. 2. The beliefs users held about the app’s accuracy and trustworthiness. 3. The perceptions users formed about the app’s design and ease of use. 4. The physical and psychological responses triggered during usage (e.g., eye strain, sense of accomplishment). 5. The behaviours users displayed while interacting with the app (e.g., checking it daily, avoiding certain features). Which of the above aspects are typically considered part of User Experience (UX)?

questions.question_text_1:
Which of the following could the course team of Design Thinking for Data-Driven App Development
do to make the upcoming term even more unforgettable? (Hint: Our team wants to give you 1 mark as a gesture of thanks for taking this course. All statements are correct.) [Check ‘All’ as answer] 1. Buy coffee for nervous participants during the project viva voce. 2. Help teams find investors if they wish to take their project work forward. 3. Award +10 bonus marks for attending all live sessions. 4. Buy Mural and Figma licenses for each team so canvases and prototypes don’t have to be drawn on napkins. Select the correct answer from the options below:
question_texts:
Which of the following could the course team of Design Thinking for Data-Driven App Development
do to make the upcoming term even more unforgettable? (Hint: Our team wants to give you 1 mark as a gesture of thanks for taking this course. All statements are correct.) [Check ‘All’ as answer] 1. Buy coffee for nervous participants during the project viva voce. 2. Help teams find investors if they wish to take their project work forward. 3. Award +10 bonus marks for attending all live sessions. 4. Buy Mural and Figma licenses for each team so canvases and prototypes don’t have to be drawn on napkins. Select the correct answer from the options below:

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the exam **"Design Thinking for Data-Driven App Development"**, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts Summary**
#### **1. Design Thinking & Human-Centered Design (HCD)**
- **Definition**: Iterative, user-focused problem-solving methodology.
- **Key Principles (Don Norman)**:
  - Meet user needs.
  - Ensure usability and understandability.
  - Create enjoyable experiences.
  - Balance design constraints (technical, business, user).
- **Phases**:
  1. **Empathize**: Understand users (interviews, observations).
  2. **Define**: Frame the problem (personas, journey maps).
  3. **Ideate**: Brainstorm solutions (divergent thinking).
  4. **Prototype**: Build low-fidelity models (paper/wireframes).
  5. **Test**: Validate with users (iterative feedback).
- **Tools**:
  - **Personas**: Fictional user profiles.
  - **Customer Journey Maps**: Visualize user interactions + emotional highs/lows.
  - **Root Cause Analysis**: "5 Whys" (Toyota).
  - **Wireframes**: Low-fidelity sketches of app screens.

#### **2. Agile + Design Thinking**
- **Agile Principles**:
  - Individuals/interactions > processes/tools.
  - Working software > documentation.
  - Customer collaboration > contract negotiation.
  - Responding to change > following a plan.
- **Design Sprints**:
  - **Benefits**:
    - Validate ideas quickly (before coding).
    - Reduce waste (unwanted features).
    - Align teams on user needs.
  - **Process**: 5-day sprint (map → sketch → decide → prototype → test).

#### **3. Double Diamond Design Process**
- **Phases**:
  1. **Discover (Diverge)**: Explore problems broadly.
  2. **Define (Converge)**: Narrow to a specific problem.
  3. **Develop (Diverge)**: Generate solutions.
  4. **Deliver (Converge)**: Finalize and implement.
- **Axes in Diagram**:
  - **X-axis**: Time.
  - **Y-axis**: Number of alternatives (divergence) or focus (convergence).

#### **4. UX Design Principles**
- **Simplicity vs. Minimalism**:
  - Simplicity: Reduce complexity.
  - Minimalism: Reduce elements to the bare minimum.
- **Peak-End Rule**: Users remember:
  - **Peak** (most intense moment).
  - **End** (final interaction).
- **User Testing**:
  - Test with target users.
  - Mimic real-world conditions.
  - Use paired participants for discussion.

#### **5. TRIZ (Theory of Inventive Problem Solving)**
- **Principles**:
  - **Preliminary Action**: Prepare in advance (e.g., AI grammar predictions).
  - **Merging**: Combine functions (e.g., pen + stylus).
  - **Feedback**: Dynamic adjustments (e.g., adaptive quizzes).
  - **Universality**: Multi-functional tools.
- **Goal**: Systematic innovation by resolving contradictions.

#### **6. Intellectual Property (IP)**
- **Types**:
  - **Copyright**: Protects original expressions (not ideas).
  - **Patents**: Protect novel, non-obvious inventions.
  - **Trademarks**: Protect brand identifiers (logos, names).
  - **Trade Secrets**: Confidential info (no public disclosure required).
- **Ownership**:
  - If invented under employment contract, **company typically owns IP** (even if developed on personal time).

#### **7. Prototyping & Testing**
- **Prototyping**:
  - Low-fidelity (paper sketches) → High-fidelity (interactive mockups).
- **Cost Metrics**:
  - **Cost Per Install (CPI)** = Total Spend / Number of Installs.
    - Example: ₹8,400 / 300 installs = **₹28 per install**.

#### **8. Intrapreneurship**
- **Definition**: Entrepreneurial behavior within a company.
- **Example**: Employee creates a new product/app for their employer.

#### **9. Effective Communication (PRESENT Method)**
- **Story Structures**:
  1. **Start-Middle-End**.
  2. **Context-Conflict/Challenge-Solution**.

#### **10. User Experience (UX) Evaluation**
- **Aspects to Measure**:
  - Emotional reactions.
  - Beliefs about accuracy/trust.
  - Perceptions of design/usability.
  - Physical/psychological responses.
  - User behaviors (e.g., daily usage).

---

### **Key Equations (Math-Related)**
1. **Cost Per Install (CPI)**:
   \[
   CPI = \frac{\text{Total Marketing Spend}}{\text{Number of Installs}}
   \]
   - Example: ₹8,400 / 300 = ₹28 per install.

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **Graph 1: Design Thinking Process**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Empathize] --> B[Define]
    B --> C[Ideate]
    C --> D[Prototype]
    D --> E[Test]
    E -->|Iterate| C
    style A fill:#f9f,stroke:#333
    style B fill:#bbf,stroke:#333
    style C fill:#f96,stroke:#333
    style D fill:#6f9,stroke:#333
    style E fill:#9cf,stroke:#333
```

#### **Graph 2: Agile + Design Thinking Integration**
```mermaid
graph LR
    AG[Agile] -->|Customer Collaboration| DT[Design Thinking]
    AG -->|Iterative Development| DT
    DT -->|User-Centric Problems| AG
    DT -->|Prototyping| AG
    style AG fill:#f96,stroke:#333
    style DT fill:#9cf,stroke:#333
```

#### **Graph 3: Double Diamond Model**
```mermaid
graph TD
    D1[Discover\n(Diverge)] --> D2[Define\n(Converge)]
    D2 --> D3[Develop\n(Diverge)]
    D3 --> D4[Deliver\n(Converge)]
    D1 -->|Time| D4
    D1 -->|Alternatives| D3
    style D1 fill:#f96,stroke:#333
    style D2 fill:#9cf,stroke:#333
    style D3 fill:#f96,stroke:#333
    style D4 fill:#9cf,stroke:#333
```

#### **Graph 4: TRIZ Principles**
```mermaid
graph TD
    TRIZ[TRIZ Principles] --> PA[Preliminary Action]
    TRIZ --> M[Merging]
    TRIZ --> F[Feedback]
    TRIZ --> U[Universality]
    PA -->|Example| AI[AI Grammar Tool]
    M -->|Example| Pen[2-in-1 Pen]
    F -->|Example| Quiz[Adaptive Quizzes]
    style TRIZ fill:#f9f,stroke:#333
    style PA fill:#bbf,stroke:#333
    style M fill:#f96,stroke:#333
    style F fill:#6f9,stroke:#333
    style U fill:#9cf,stroke:#333
```

#### **Graph 5: Intellectual Property Types**
```mermaid
graph TD
    IP[Intellectual Property] --> C[Copyright]
    IP --> P[Patent]
    IP --> T[Trademark]
    IP --> TS[Trade Secret]
    C -->|Protects| Expression[Original Expressions]
    P -->|Requires| Novelty[Novel + Non-Obvious]
    T -->|Protects| Brand[Logos, Names]
    TS -->|Requires| Secrecy[Confidentiality]
    style IP fill:#f9f,stroke:#333
    style C fill:#f96,stroke:#333
    style P fill:#9cf,stroke:#333
    style T fill:#6f9,stroke:#333
    style TS fill:#bbf,stroke:#333
```

---
### **Exam Tips**
1. **For Problem-Solving (Q3)**:
   - Use the **Double Diamond** framework.
   - Start with **personas/journey maps** → **root cause** → **ideation** → **wireframes**.
2. **For MCQs**:
   - Focus on **Agile principles**, **TRIZ examples**, and **UX evaluation aspects**.
3. **Math**:
   - Only **CPI calculation** is needed (Q14).
4. **IP Questions**:
   - Remember: **Company owns IP if invented under employment**.
